A 28-year-old man with a history of psoriasis presents to the emergency department reporting several weeks of dyspnea, subjective fevers, and malaise. He is currently being treated with adalimumab.
On examination, his vital signs are within normal limits. There is dullness to percussion and absent breath sounds over the right lung base. There are several patches of silvery-white plaques over his knees and elbows. Results of a complete blood count, comprehensive metabolic panel, and liver function tests are within normal limits.
A chest radiograph is obtained (figure).
Diagnostic thoracentesis reveals a leukocyte count of 1682 per μL with 92% lymphocytes, protein 4.9 mg/dL, lactate dehydrogenase 149 U/liter, glucose 60 mg/dL, pH 7.6, adenosine deaminase 55 U/liter (normal, ≤ 14), and a triglyceride level of 80 mg/dL. Gram stain, acid-fast bacillus stain, and cultures of the fluid are negative.
Laboratory testing shows a total protein of 7.0 g/dL (reference range, 5.5–8.0) and a lactate dehydrogenase of 182 U/liter (100–190).
Which one of the following management approaches is most appropriate in this patient's evaluation?

choices.text: Measurement of pleural fluid carcinoembryonic antigen

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Tuberculous effusions should be suspected in patients with pleural effusions of unclear etiology who have risk factors for Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection, in this case being treated with adalimumab. Pleural fluid cell count and differential can help define the etiology of a pleural effusion. A lymphocytic predominance indicates a chronic process, usually due to either tuberculosis or malignancy. Although there is variability in the reported yield of pleural fluid cultures in patients with tuberculous pleural effusion, most larger series report that only 20% to 30% are fluid culture positive. Pleural biopsy and culture can increase the yield to > 90%. An elevated pleural adenosine deaminase (ADA) level (> 40 U/L) is highly suggestive of tuberculous pleural effusion, particularly when clinical suspicion is high.

Pleural fluid cytology would be indicated if the patient had a malignant pleural effusion. Although this patient is at risk for lymphoma because of his use of adalimumab, an elevated ADA level strongly suggests tuberculosis, and next steps should be directed toward confirming that diagnosis.

Key learning point: The most appropriate test to evaluate a lymphocyte-predominant exudative pleural effusion in a patient with risk factors for tuberculosis is a pleural biopsy.

B) INCORRECT:

Measurement of pleural fluid amylase is useful in patients with pancreatitis and a concomitant pleural effusion. This patient has no features to suggest pancreatitis.

C) INCORRECT:

Biopsy of a skin plaque is unlikely to be helpful other than to confirm the diagnosis of psoriasis.

D) INCORRECT:

It is not clear that measurement of pleural fluid carcinoembryonic antigen is helpful in diagnosing malignant effusions and would not assist in managing this patient because there is minimal concern for malignancy.

E) INCORRECT:

Thoracic lymphangiogram would be helpful if the fluid analysis revealed a chylothorax, but this is not the case with a normal pleural fluid triglyceride level.

Although pleural biopsy is sometimes appropriate for the diagnosis of pleural metastases, performing this test before repeat cytopathologic examination of pleural fluid would be unnecessarily invasive. About a quarter of those that remain undiagnosed will have positive cytology on repeat sampling; there is little additional yield with subsequent samples. questions.text:
A 9-year-old boy is hospitalized with respiratory distress and a 7-day history of fever and cough. Two days before the admission, he was started on oral amoxicillin, but it did not significantly improve his symptoms. During the past 24 hours, his respiratory distress has worsened, and he now complains of chest pain with inspiration and abdominal pain on his right side. He is up to date with all vaccinations, including Covid-19, and testing for SARS-CoV-2 is negative.
His temperature is 39.2°C, his heart rate is 122 beats per minute, his respiratory rate is 32 breaths per minute, his blood pressure is 102/52 mm Hg, and his oxygen saturation is 93% while he breathes ambient air. He is uncomfortable and in mild respiratory distress. Reduced breath sounds and egophony are evident at the right base. There are no murmurs, rubs, or gallops.
A chest radiograph (figure) and ultrasound confirm a small, free-flowing parapneumonic effusion.
In addition to initiating intravenous cefotaxime, which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Obtain a CT scan of the chest
Perform thoracentesis and evaluate the fluid characteristics

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Treatment with gentamicin is not typically indicated in this setting.

B) INCORRECT:

CT of the chest can determine the size of the effusion and define areas of loculation and empyema however, ultrasound is preferred because it does not use radiation and can accurately characterize whether the fluid is free-flowing. When one needs to accurately estimate the size of the effusion and determine whether the fluid is free-flowing, the preferred imaging modality is ultrasound.

C) INCORRECT:

Placement of a chest tube may be necessary if the boy’s clinical condition worsens, but it should be performed after further characterization of the pleural fluid. In some instances, a chest tube alone is insufficient, and further surgical intervention with video-assisted thoracoscopy is the more optimal treatment, particularly in cases where the fluid has become organized and there are areas of loculation. Early consultation with a pulmonary specialist can help ensure that care is expedited if the course of illness worsens.

D) INCORRECT:

Pneumonia associated with a small pleural effusion, as is notable on this patient's radiograph, can be managed medically without thoracentesis or surgical intervention.

E) CORRECT:

This child’s radiograph shows a right-middle and lower-lobe pneumonia as well as blunting of the costophrenic angle. The patient’s clinical symptoms and radiographic findings point to a complicated community-acquired pneumonia (CAP) with a small parapneumonic effusion.

Complex pneumonias with parapneumonic processes can be associated with typical bacterial infections, such as Streptococcus pneumoniae and Staphylococcus aureus. However, atypical infections, such as Mycoplasma pneumoniae and Chlamydophila pneumoniae, can also cause pleural effusion and are the most common causes of CAP in school-age children, particularly those who have been completely vaccinated with both pneumococcal and Haemophilus influenzae vaccines.

This patient initially received amoxicillin (a narrow-spectrum beta-lactam antibiotic). Although amoxicillin alone is recommended as first-line therapy for children with mild-to-moderate CAP, it does not provide sufficient coverage for atypical pathogens such as those mentioned above. A broader-spectrum beta-lactam antibiotic (such as cefotaxime) should be initiated, and a macrolide antibiotic (such as azithromycin) may also be considered. There is increasing evidence that adding a macrolide to beta-lactam therapy provides only limited benefit in the treatment of CAP, but in this case, it is warranted, as the patient has not responded to outpatient beta-lactam therapy and is now presenting in respiratory distress with a parapneumonic effusion.

The size of the effusion and the degree of respiratory compromise are important factors in determining the optimal management of a complicated pneumonia.

Large effusions, involving more than half of the hemithorax, almost always require surgical intervention.

Key learning point: In addition to cefotaxime, the antibiotic class that should be added when treating a child with community-acquired pneumonia is a macrolide to cover atypical pneumonia.

questions.text: A 49-year-old man comes to the hospital for a 10-day history of cough and worsening shortness of breath. He has sharp right-sided chest pain that worsens on inspiration and coughing. He has coronary artery disease and hypertension. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3° F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 29/min, and blood pressure is 110/65 mmHg. Examination shows dullness to percussion at the base of the right lung. Crackles and markedly decreased breath sounds are heard over the right middle and lower lung fields. A chest x-ray study of the chest shows a right-sided loculated pleural effusion and consolidation of the surrounding lung with visible air bronchogram; there are no rib fractures. Thoracocentesis is performed. Examination of this patient's pleural fluid is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Pleural fluid protein to serum protein ratio of 0.4

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Increased pleural fluid amylase levels (≥ upper limit of normal serum amylase) are associated with esophageal rupture (e.g., secondary to repeated vomiting), pancreatic diseases (e.g., acute pancreatitis), and certain malignancies (e.g., lung cancer). Pleural fluid amylase levels are not routinely obtained but should be measured if esophageal rupture or pancreatic disease is suspected. This patient's clinical and radiological findings indicate exudative parapneumonic effusion, which does not manifest as an amylase-rich pleural effusion.

B) INCORRECT:

Pleural fluid lymphocytosis with a lymphocyte value ≥ 90% is associated with tuberculosis and certain malignancies (e.g., lymphoma) that may also manifest with fever, cough, and dyspnea. However, because this patient does not have other symptoms of tuberculosis or malignancy, such as weight loss, night sweats, fatigue, or lymphadenopathy, he is more likely to have a neutrophilic (not lymphocytic), parapneumonic effusion.

C) INCORRECT:

Per Light's criteria, a pleural fluid lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) level < ⅔ of the upper limit of normal serum LDH levels (200 U/L) indicates transudative pleural effusion. This patient's history of coronary artery disease and hypertension puts him at increased risk for congestive heart failure and subsequent development of pleural transudate. However, his clinical and radiological findings indicate exudative parapneumonic effusion, which typically manifests with LDH levels > ⅔ of the upper limit of normal serum LDH levels.

D) CORRECT:

Pleural fluid glucose levels < 60 mg/dL suggest exudative pleural effusion, and, in the context of pneumonia, a complicated parapneumonic effusion or pleural empyema. Parapneumonic effusion typically manifests with decreased pleural fluid glucose levels due to increased glucose metabolization by leukocytes and bacteria. Other conditions associated with an exudative pleural effusion include malignancies (e.g., mesothelioma), tuberculosis, rheumatoid arthritis, and systemic lupus erythematosus. Pleural fluid glucose levels ≥ 60 mg/dL suggest a transudate, e.g., due to congestive heart failure (see “Adjunctive pleural fluid analysis” table).

Chest tube placement and systemic antibiotic therapy are the preferred treatment for complicated parapneumonic effusion and pleural empyema.

E) INCORRECT:

One of Light's criteria of pleural effusions is the pleural fluid protein:serum protein ratio, which is ≤ 0.5 in transudates. This patient's history of coronary artery disease and hypertension put him at increased risk for congestive heart failure and subsequent development of pleural transudate. His clinical and radiological findings, however, indicate exudative, parapneumonic effusion, which typically manifests with a pleural fluid protein to serum protein ratio of > 0.5.
questions.hint: This patient's presentation with fever, cough, as well as crackles and decreased breath sounds on pulmonary auscultation is consistent with pneumonia. The chest x-ray findings of air bronchogram and pleural effusion suggest parapneumonic effusion or pleural empyema.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of worsening shortness of breath and a productive cough for 3 days. He sustained trauma to the right hemithorax during a fight 3 weeks ago. He had significant pain and mild shortness of breath following the incident but did not seek medical care. His temperature is 38.4°C (101.1°F), pulse is 95/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 120/75 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 96%. Pulmonary examination shows decreased breath sounds over the right lower lung fields. CT scan of the chest shows fractures of the right 7th and 8th ribs, right pleural splitting and thickening, and a dense fluid collection in the pleural space. Which of the following is the most likely explanation of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Viral pleurisy can cause a transudative pleural effusion but is an unlikely diagnosis given that there is no report of pleuritic chest pain. There is also no history of recent upper respiratory symptoms (other than a cough) or fever prior to presentation that makes this etiology likely. The history of blunt trauma to the chest prior to presentation also suggests a different diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

While decreased breath sounds and presence of a fever make a lung abscess possible, the collection of fluid in the pleural space suggests a pleural process rather than an intraparenchymal problem. In addition, the split pleural sign is not associated with a lung abscess.
Image Description:

CT chest (axial plane; lung window) of a patient with pneumonia and lung abscesses

Two thick-walled cavitary lesions (green overlay) are seen in the right middle lobe. A sharp air-fluid level is visible within the anterior cavity. Air bronchograms (examples indicated by red overlays) are present within the surrounding consolidation.

C) INCORRECT:

A hemothorax is possible following blunt trauma to the chest, but associated signs (e.g., decreased breath sounds) and symptoms (e.g., shortness of breath) would likely appear sooner than 3 weeks after the injury. In addition, hemothorax is not associated with fever. It is likely that this patient initially had a hemothorax and developed a complication causing his current presentation because the blood in the pleural space was not drained.

D) INCORRECT:

A chylothorax is possible following blunt trauma to the chest, but associated signs (decreased breath sounds) and symptoms (shortness of breath, cough) would likely appear sooner than 3 weeks after the injury. In addition, fever is unlikely to occur with a chylothorax. CT imaging of a chylothorax will show dense fluid density collection in the pleural space, but it is not associated with the split pleura sign.

E) CORRECT:

The presence of a dense fluid collection in the pleural space, split pleura sign and fever suggests the diagnosis of pleural empyema. If present, loculations on CT are also associated with a diagnosis of pleural empyema. Empyemas most often result from the progression of an uncomplicated (sterile) parapneumonic effusion that becomes complicated (infected) and forms frank pus, but can also occur following a traumatic hemothorax, as in this patient. Treatment for empyemas involves chest tube placement to drain the empyema fluid and systemic antibiotic treatment. This may be followed by thoracoscopic debridement if the empyema does not resolve after chest tube drainage.
Image Description:

CT chest (with contrast; axial plane; mediastinal window)

CT scan shows right-sided pleural fluid collection (PC). The collection has a lenticular (biconvex) shape and is accompanied by thickening of the adjacent parietal (red line) and visceral pleurae (green line).

The split-pleura sign refers to thickening and contrast enhancement of the parietal and visceral pleurae separated by empyema or exudative effusion. The sign is the result of a fibrin pleural coat with capillary ingrowth and is considered reliable in distinguishing empyema from lung abscess. Lung abscesses, furthermore, tend to be round in contrast to the lenticular shape typical of empyemas.

T: trachea
questions.hint: A CT scan in individuals with this patient's condition may also show a loculated pleural fluid collection.

questions.text: A 64-year-old man comes to the emergency department for the evaluation of fever, malaise, dyspnea, and a worsening productive cough over the past 3 days. He has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and alcoholic cirrhosis. He drinks 3–4 beers per day and smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years but quit 5 years ago. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 95/min, respirations are 20/min. A chest x-ray study shows a flattened diaphragm, an increased anteroposterior diameter, increased radiolucency of the parenchyma on the left, and air bronchograms on the right. A lateral decubitus view shows a pleural effusion on the right. Thoracentesis yields pleural fluid analysis shows a pH of 7.3. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's effusion?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Parapneumonic pleural effusions are typically exudative. Pneumonia is associated with pleural inflammation, which leads to increased pleural vascular permeability, causing capillary leakage of exudate. Although exudative and transudative pleural effusions are usually differentiated by Light's criteria, a pleural fluid pH of < 7.3 - 7.45 also suggests an exudative rather than transudative effusion, which typically has a pH of 7.45–7.55. In exudative pleural effusions, the anaerobic metabolic activity of both bacteria and leukocytes accumulating in the pleural fluid transforms glucose into lactate, which leads to a decrease in pleural fluid pH. Early antibiotic treatment is indicated to prevent progression to complicated effusion and empyema. See “Adjunctive pleural fluid analysis” table.

Complicated parapneumonic effusions, defined by pleural fluid pH < 7.2, elevated lactate dehydrogenase, and/or glucose < 60 mg/dL, are an indication for chest tube placement because this type of effusion is less likely to resolve spontaneously.
Image Description:

Normal: Capillary hydrostatic pressure (driving fluid out of capillaries) and capillary oncotic pressure (keeping fluid within capillaries) are roughly balanced.

Transudate is extravascular fluid caused by increased capillary hydrostatic pressure (e.g., in congestive heart failure) or decreased capillary oncotic pressure (e.g., in hypoalbuminemia). Transudate has a low protein and cell content and, therefore, tends to be clear.

Exudate is extravascular fluid caused by increased capillary permeability (e.g., secondary to inflammation or malignancy). Exudate has a high protein and cell content and, therefore, tends to be yellow or cloudy.

B) INCORRECT:

Increased pulmonary capillary pressure is the underlying mechanism of pleural effusions in individuals with left heart failure. The inability of the heart to pump blood forward causes a backup of blood into the left atrium and the pulmonary veins. This backup increases the hydrostatic pressure in the pulmonary vasculature (pulmonary capillary wedge pressure), leading to pulmonary edema and transudative pleural effusions. Transudative effusions typically have a pH of 7.45–7.55, whereas this patient's effusion has a pH of 7.3. Moreover, signs and symptoms of left-sided heart failure would be expected bilaterally, unlike the unilateral parapneumonic effusion seen here.

C) INCORRECT:

Decreased plasma oncotic pressure is the underlying pathomechanism of pleural effusions in cirrhosis and/or nephrotic syndrome. Both conditions lead to reduced serum concentrations of albumin, the main serum protein that maintains intravascular oncotic pressure. Consequently, fluid extravasates into the interstitial space, resulting in a transudative effusion with a pH of 7.45–7.55. This patient's pleural effusion has a pH of 7.3. Although this patient has a history of alcoholic cirrhosis, he does not present with symptoms of either condition.

D) INCORRECT:

Transdiaphragmatic fluid movement causes hepatic hydrothorax, a pulmonary complication of cirrhosis that is most commonly right-sided and manifests with dyspnea. Although this patient has a history of alcoholic cirrhosis, he has no signs of ascites (e.g., abdominal distention), which would be expected in this condition. Moreover, hepatic hydrothorax is a transudative effusion, which usually has a pH of 7.45–7.55. This patient's pleural fluid pH of 7.3 suggests an exudative effusion.

E) INCORRECT:

Impaired lymphatic flow results in chylothorax, an exudative effusion. Chylothorax is commonly caused by thoracic duct obstruction due to malignancy (e.g., non-Hodgkin lymphoma, lung cancer) or thoracic duct injury (e.g., due to thoracic surgery or severe trauma). Although this patient's history of smoking increases his risk of lung cancer, he lacks systemic features of malignancy such as weight loss. Moreover, he has no history of recent trauma or surgery.
questions.hint: Fever, dyspnea, and worsening productive cough in combination with air bronchograms on chest x-ray in a patient with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) indicate an acute exacerbation of COPD triggered by pneumonia. This patient most likely developed a parapneumonic effusion, a type of exudate.

questions.text: A 61-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of shortness of breath and right-sided chest pain for 3 days. The pain is sharp and worsens with deep inspiration. He has also had a fever and a cough productive of yellow sputum for 5 days. His temperature is 38.1°C (100.5°F), pulse is 85/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 132/85 mm Hg. Physical examination shows dullness to percussion at the bases of the right lung; breath sounds are diminished over the right middle and lower lobes. A chest x-ray study shows blunting of the right costophrenic angle. Pleural fluid obtained via diagnostic thoracocentesis shows a pH of 7.1 and glucose concentration of 55 mg/dL. In addition to broad-spectrum antibiotics, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intravenous furosemide is used to resolve transudative pleural effusion due to congestive heart failure (CHF). This patient has a parapneumonic effusion, which is an exudate, not a transudate. Moreover, this patient has no signs of CHF (e.g., nocturia, S4/S3 gallop).

B) INCORRECT:

Deoxyribonuclease (DNase) is a mucolytic agent that reduces pleural fluid viscosity and prevents or dissolves loculations. Intrapleural administration of DNase can be used to facilitate drainage of complicated parapneumonic effusions, but it is not considered first-line therapy and is not recommended as monotherapy.

C) INCORRECT:

Pleural decortication is an invasive procedure that involves the surgical removal of restrictive layers of fibrous tissue overlying the lung to allow better lung compliance and expansion. Pleural decortication is indicated in patients with recurrent effusions or effusions refractory to less invasive techniques. This patient should first be managed with a less invasive treatment option.

D) CORRECT:

Chest tube placement (i.e., tube thoracostomy) is indicated for a patient with pleural fluid pH < 7.20 and glucose < 60 mg/dL. These findings suggest that parapneumonic effusion has progressed to pleural empyema, which is unlikely to resolve spontaneously. In addition to tube thoracostomy, all patients with pleural empyema should receive empiric antibiotic therapy. If tube drainage is inefficient (e.g., due to septation of the pleural fluid), further treatments, such as intrapleural administration of fibrinolytic agents, thoracoscopic debridement, and pleurectomy with lung decortication, may be necessary.

E) INCORRECT:

Thoracoscopic debridement is an invasive procedure reserved for patients with complicated parapneumonic effusions that have not responded to less invasive treatment. This patient should first be managed with a less invasive treatment option.
questions.hint: This patient's history of productive cough and fever that progressed to shortness of breath and pleuritic chest pain suggests pneumonia complicated by a parapneumonic effusion.

questions.text:
A 79-year-old woman comes to the office for the evaluation of a 2-month history of a nonproductive cough and fatigue. During this period, she also has had a 4.5-kg (10-lb) weight loss and has become increasingly short of breath with mild exertion. She has congestive heart failure. Three months ago, she was in India for 3 weeks. She worked as a seamstress in a textile factory for 50 years. There is dullness to percussion and decreased breath sounds over the right lung base. Laboratory studies show a glucose level of 90 mg/dL, serum lactate dehydrogenase of 227 U/L, and serum protein of 6.3 g/dL. An x-ray of the chest shows nodular pleural lesions on the right side and a moderate-sized pleural effusion. Thoracentesis shows 250 mL of turbid fluid. Analysis of the pleural fluid aspirate shows:


Erythrocyte count
1/mm3



Leukocyte count
4000/mm3



Glucose
59 mg/dl


Lactate dehydrogenase
248 U/L


Protein
3.8 g/dL


Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's effusion?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Bronchial adenocarcinoma could manifest with an exudative malignant pleural effusion, and smoking and asbestos exposure both increase the risk of lung cancer. However, the x-ray shows pleural lesions rather than a parenchymal lung lesion, making the diagnosis of lung cancer less likely.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (A: PA view) and CT chest (B: coronal plane; lung window) of a patient with pulmonary adenocarcinoma

A spiculated nodule is seen in the upper lobe of the right lung (white arrows).

RULB = Right upper lobe bronchus

B) INCORRECT:

Nephrotic syndrome would result in a clear, transudative pleural effusion from decreased oncotic pressure, not a turbid, exudative pleural effusion. Furthermore, other findings commonly seen in nephrotic syndrome, such as edema, frothy urine, hypertension, or signs of hypocalcemia, are absent in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Cough, weight loss, travel to a country with high tuberculosis (TB) incidence, and exudative pleural effusion are consistent with TB. However, isolated, unilateral, nodular pleural lesions are not common x-ray findings in TB. Typical x-ray findings include consolidation, hilar lymphadenopathy, and, in reactivation TB, fibrocaseous cavitary lesions.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA view; insert: axial CT, lung window) of a patient with postprimary tuberculosis

A thick-walled irregularly shaped cavity (green overlay) in the left lung apex is surrounded by micronodular opacities (examples indicated by dotted lines), which are better seen on the CT image than on the chest radiograph.

The differential diagnosis for a cavitary lung lesion includes both infectious (bacterial, fungal, and occasionally parasitic) and noninfectious (malignant, inflammatory, vascular, and traumatic) etiologies. In postprimary tuberculosis, the apicoposterior segments of the upper lobes and superior segments of the lower lobes are common sites of involvement. A thick-walled cavity accompanied by consolidation or nodular opacities can signify active disease.

D) INCORRECT:

Although the patient has congestive heart failure (CHF), CHF would typically manifest with a clear, transudative effusion from increased hydrostatic pressure in pulmonary capillaries.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (AP view)

The cardiac silhouette is enlarged (hatched green overlay) and the perihilar air space opacities (green overlay) have a bat wing, or butterfly, configuration. Linear interstitial opacities representing Kerley A lines (orange dashed lines) radiate from the hila to the apices and Kerley B lines (white dashed lines) are seen in the lateral mid zones. The costophrenic angles are blunted (arrows) from bilateral pleural effusions.

These features are characteristically seen in cardiogenic pulmonary edema.

E) CORRECT:

This patient's x-ray findings (nodular pleural lesions) and history of asbestos exposure suggest mesothelioma, a neoplastic process of the mesothelium that can manifest with malignant pleural effusion. Malignant effusion is caused by cancer-related barrier dysfunction of the capillary walls, which leads to increased permeation of plasma protein, blood cells, and tumor cells. These effusions are usually exudative and cell-rich, with a cloudy or straw-like appearance, abnormal cytology, a glucose concentration < 60 mg/dL, pH < 7.2, and high concentrations of LDH (> 0.45 x normal serum LDH) and amylase (> 200 mg/dL).

In addition to addressing the underlying malignancy, symptomatic malignant pleural effusions can be treated with therapeutic thoracocentesis and, if the effusion is expected to reaccumulate rapidly or frequently, an indwelling pleural catheter or chemical pleurodesis.
Image Description:

CT chest (with contrast; coronal plane) of a patient with malignant mesothelioma

Nodular pleural thickening (hatched green overlay) encases the left lung and the volume of the left hemithorax (red dashed line) is reduced compared to the right (green dashed line). Enlarged mediastinal lymph nodes are present (red overlay).

The findings are compatible with malignant mesothelioma, although confluent pleural metastatic disease can have a similar appearance. Both primary and secondary pleural malignancies can cause pleural nodules, diffuse pleural thickening, and pleural effusion.

AO: aorta; LV: left ventricle; PA: pulmonary artery
questions.hint: This patient presents with chronic fatigue, nonproductive cough, weight loss, and nodular pleural lesions on x-ray, the combination of which raises concern for malignancy. Her work as a seamstress in a textile factory for 50 years is a risk factor for asbestos exposure. Based on Light's criteria (effusion protein: serum protein ratio > 0.5 and effusion LDH: serum LDH ratio > 0.6), this patient has an exudative pleural effusion.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of increasing shortness of breath and a nonproductive cough for the last week. Three weeks ago, he had a fever and a cough for 6 days. He has had a 4-kg (9-lb) weight loss over the past 3 months. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 41 years. His temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 136/89 mm Hg. There is dullness to percussion, decreased breath sounds, and decreased tactile fremitus over the left lung base. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. Chest x-ray of this patient is most likely to show which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ground-glass opacities in the lungs can be seen on chest x-ray in the course of infections (e.g., pneumocystis pneumonia), interstitial lung disease (e.g., pulmonary fibrosis), and acute alveolar disease (e.g., pulmonary edema). While all of these conditions may manifest with dyspnea and cough, further characteristic symptoms are absent (e.g., fever, protracted disease course, crackles or rales on auscultation). In addition, ground-glass opacities are frequently hard to detect on x-ray and are better visualized on CT scan.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA view) of a patient with Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP)

Bilateral opacification of the lungs is visible in a perihilar (bat wing or butterfly) distribution (green overlay). This pattern of involvement can be seen in a variety of diseases, including pulmonary edema (cardiogenic and noncardiogenic), pneumonia, inhalational lung injury, pulmonary hemorrhage, pulmonary alveolar proteinosis, and malignancy. Low lung volumes and cardiac silhouette enlargement, which may accompany cardiogenic edema, are not present on this radiograph.

Bilateral perihilar opacification is a common presentation of PCP pneumonia and may have a granular, reticular, or airspace appearance on chest radiography. PCP may also present with lung cysts and pneumothorax. A ground-glass appearance is commonly described on CT. Nodules, cavities, lymphadenopathy, and pleural effusions are uncommon.

B) INCORRECT:

Widening of the intercostal spaces on chest x-ray is caused by chronic hyperinflation of the lungs in emphysema. Emphysema is most commonly seen in individuals with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, which manifests with a chronic productive cough and gradually worsening dyspnea. While tobacco use is the greatest risk factor for developing emphysema, this patient's rapid onset of symptoms makes another diagnosis more likely.
Image Description:

Chest x-ray (PA view)

Large lung volumes (green outline and arrows) are accompanied by intercostal space widening (examples indicated by red arrows) and diaphragmatic flattening, indicating hyperinflation.

C) INCORRECT:

A positive air bronchogram in a patient with dyspnea and a history of cough could indicate lobar pneumonia or alveolar edema. Lobar pneumonia typically manifests with a productive cough, enhanced tactile fremitus, and crackles on auscultation, while alveolar edema manifests with orthopnea and rales and wheezing on auscultation.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA and lateral views) of a patient with pneumonia

There is heterogeneous right upper lobe consolidation (green overlay) with air bronchograms (examples of bronchial walls indicated by white lines). The major (white dashed line) and minor fissures (red dashed lines) are elevated from normal position as a result of accompanying atelectasis. No hilar enlargement or pleural effusion is seen.

The differential diagnosis for airspace consolidation considers the radiographic appearance, associated findings (e.g., lymphadenopathy, pleural effusion), and patient history and symptoms. Pneumonia, hemorrhage, edema, tumor, and protein can all present as consolidation on a chest radiograph.

Green line: aortic arch margin; LL: lower lobe; ML: middle lobe; UL: upper lobe

D) INCORRECT:

The deep sulcus sign is a diagnostic finding in patients with pneumothorax. This patient's history of smoking significantly increases his risk of developing a pneumothorax. However, this condition typically manifests with sudden onset of dyspnea and chest pain, as well as hyperresonance on percussion, and is therefore unlikely in this patient.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (AP view; supine)

A pneumothorax is visible in the left pleural space. The air has displaced the visceral pleura medially (arrowheads), portions of which are seen as a thin white curvilinear opacity. Pleural air has reduced the density of the lower left hemithorax compared to the right and has widened the left lateral costophrenic angle (deep sulcus sign, red overlay).

Pneumothorax collects anteriorly and basally within the nondependent pleural space when a patient is positioned supine. Air located laterally can abnormally deepen the lateral costophrenic angle. The deep sulcus sign is sometimes the only finding of pneumothorax in a supine patient.

Blue overlay: endotracheal tube; green overlay: atelectasis; yellow overlay: left internal jugular line

E) CORRECT:

Blunting of the costophrenic angle is a diagnostic feature of pleural effusion seen on chest x-ray that is caused by the collection of free pleural fluid in the costophrenic recess. Further radiographic features of pleural effusion include a homogeneous density with a meniscus-shaped margin (meniscus sign) as well as complete opacification of the lung and mediastinal shift to the contralateral side in cases of large effusions. Thoracentesis is the most effective method for managing pleural effusion and also allows for analysis of the pleural fluid to help establish the underlying etiology.

This patient's recent weight loss and long history of cigarette smoking suggest that the most likely cause of pleural effusion is lung cancer. A chest CT is indicated to evaluate for signs of malignancy and rule out differential diagnoses (e.g., tuberculosis).

Key learning point: Blunting of the costophrenic angle on chest x-ray is a classic radiographic sign of pleural effusion due to fluid accumulation in the pleural space.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA view) of a patient with malignant mesothelioma

Marked opacification of the middle and lower left hemithorax (green overlay) is accompanied by menisci that indicate the presence of a pleural effusion. There is no appreciable ipsilateral or contralateral mediastinal shift. Non-dependent pleural thickening at the left apex (red overlay) is more conspicuous on the lateral radiograph.

A meniscus from a small right pleural effusion (yellow overlay) is also visible.
questions.hint: Rapidly developing dyspnea and a nonproductive cough in conjunction with dullness to percussion, decreased breath sounds, and decreased tactile fremitus suggest pleural effusion.

questions.text: A 63-year-old man is transferred from a rural hospital to a tertiary care hospital because of a 3-week history of fatigue and shortness of breath. Auscultation of the lungs shows diminished breath sounds at the right lung base. His serum total protein concentration is 6.2 g/dL. Bedside ultrasonography shows an anechoic collection in the lower margins of the right pleural cavity. Thoracentesis shows clear fluid with a protein concentration of 2.7 g/dL. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's pleural effusion?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary tuberculosis can cause unilateral pleural effusion. Pleural fluid analysis in pulmonary tuberculosis typically shows exudative pleural effusion with a pleural fluid protein/serum protein ratio of > 0.5. Moreover, this patient does not have other features of pulmonary tuberculosis, such as cough, fever, weight loss, and night sweats.

B) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary sarcoidosis, although rarely associated with pleural effusion, would cause an exudative effusion. The pleural fluid on thoracentesis would appear cloudy with a pleural fluid protein/serum protein ratio of > 0.5. Moreover, this patient lacks other features of pulmonary sarcoidosis, such as cough, chest pain, and fever.

C) CORRECT:

Congestive heart failure (CHF) is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's transudative pleural effusion. In left-sided heart failure, left ventricular systolic dysfunction causes an elevation in left-sided filling pressure, resulting in elevated pulmonary capillary hydrostatic pressure and increased interstitial fluid in the lung. This fluid subsequently permeates into the pleural cavity and manifests as a pleural effusion. Pleural effusions due to CHF are typically bilateral. Unilateral effusions due to CHF usually involve the right side. Other causes of transudative pleural effusion include low protein states due to liver or kidney disease.

According to the Light criteria, fluid is likely a transudate if one of the following is present: pleural fluid protein/serum protein ratio of ≤ 0.5, pleural fluid LDH/serum LDH ratio of ≤ 0.6, and pleural fluid LDH < ⅔ the upper limit of serum LDH reference range.

D) INCORRECT:

Thoracic duct injury can cause leakage of lymphatic fluid (chyle) resulting in chylothorax. Chyle is most commonly an exudate that typically has a milky appearance, a high lipid concentration, and a pleural fluid protein/serum protein ratio of > 0.5. Additionally, individuals with chylothorax often present with a history of trauma or surgery.

E) INCORRECT:

Bacterial pneumonia can cause unilateral parapneumonic effusion as a result of the migration of interstitial pulmonary fluid across the pleura. Thoracentesis in bacterial pneumonia typically shows a cloudy exudate with a pleural fluid protein/serum protein ratio of > 0.5. Moreover, this patient does not have classic features of bacterial pneumonia, such as fever, chest pain, and purulent pleural fluid (in the case of empyema).
questions.hint: Clear fluid and a low protein count (pleural fluid protein/serum protein ratio of < 0.5) suggest transudative pleural effusion.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old man presents with a 1-week history of productive cough, high fever, and progressively worsening right-sided chest pain. He reports increased shortness of breath and notes that his symptoms began after a severe bout of chills. He denies recent weight loss and has no prior history of cardiac disease or tuberculosis exposure. Examination reveals dullness to percussion at the right lung base (see lab result and report).

Temperature
38.9 °C



Test
Result
Normal Values



Pleural fluid




 Total protein
25 g/L
10 - 20 g/L



Chest X-ray: Right lower lobe consolidation and a moderate right-sided pleural effusion
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Parapneumonic effusion is associated with bacterial pneumonia, which manifests with high fever, productive cough, and localized chest pain. The chest X-ray shows right lower lobe consolidation and a moderate pleural effusion, indicating an inflammatory response. The elevated pleural fluid protein level classifies the effusion as exudative, reflecting increased capillary permeability due to infection-induced inflammation. Inflammatory mediators increase pleural membrane permeability, allowing protein-rich fluid to accumulate in the pleural space. These clinical, radiological, and laboratory findings align with the pathophysiology of a parapneumonic effusion.

Key learning point: A parapneumonic effusion is a pleural effusion that occurs as a complication of pneumonia.

B) INCORRECT:

Malignant pleural effusion is less likely given the acute onset of symptoms, including high fever, chills, and productive cough, which suggest an infectious process. The chest X-ray shows consolidation, indicating an infective etiology. Malignant effusions typically present with chronic symptoms and may include unexplained weight loss or a history of cancer, which are not present here.

C) INCORRECT:

Congestive heart failure usually causes bilateral, transudative effusions with low protein content. The unilateral right-sided effusion, elevated pleural fluid protein, and chest X-ray consolidation suggest an exudative process. The acute symptoms of high fever, productive cough, and chest pain are uncommon in heart failure, and the absence of cardiac history further reduces the likelihood of this diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Tuberculous pleural effusion typically develops subacutely or chronically, often with systemic symptoms like weight loss and night sweats, which are absent here. The acute presentation with high fever, productive cough, and localized chest pain, along with right lower lobe consolidation, suggests bacterial pneumonia rather than tuberculosis. The pleural fluid profile, with modestly elevated protein, aligns more with acute inflammation than tuberculosis, which often shows a lymphocytic exudate and low glucose levels.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man presents with a week of productive cough with yellowish sputum, persistent fever, and pleuritic chest pain. He complains of worsening shortness of breath and appears ill. Examination reveals decreased breath sounds over the right lower chest and dullness to percussion. Laboratory studies show leukocytosis with neutrophil predominance (see lab results).


Test
Result
Normal Values



Pleural fluid




 pH
6.9
7.36 - 7.45


 Glucose
1.5 mmol/L
> 2.2 mmol/L


 LDH
300 U/L
< 200 U/L



Which diagnosis is most likely?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Tuberculous pleuritis typically presents with a lymphocyte-dominant effusion and evolves over weeks, reflecting a subacute or chronic inflammatory response. The clinical presentation of sudden onset productive cough, high fever, and pleuritic chest pain, along with neutrophil-predominant leukocytosis, aligns more with an acute bacterial process, not tuberculous pleuritis.

B) INCORRECT:

Malignant pleural effusions, while exudative, generally do not exhibit severe acidosis and hypoglycorrhachia without infection. The acute symptoms of productive cough, fever, and pleuritic chest pain, along with the pleural fluid analysis, suggest an infectious process rather than malignancy, which typically presents more insidiously.

C) INCORRECT:

Simple parapneumonic effusions are characterized by modest exudative changes, with a pH above 7.2, relatively preserved glucose levels, and mild LDH elevations. The markedly low pH of 6.9, decreased glucose of 1.5 mmol/L, and elevated LDH of 300 U/L indicate a significant inflammatory process inconsistent with a simple parapneumonic effusion.

D) CORRECT:

Empyema manifests with pleural fluid that is notably acidic, as indicated by a pH of 6.9, due to bacterial metabolism and inflammatory byproducts. The low glucose level of 1.5 mmol/L results from increased utilization by neutrophils and bacteria, along with impaired transport across the inflamed pleural membrane. An elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) of 300 U/L signifies extensive cell turnover and tissue destruction. These findings, combined with symptoms of pneumonia such as fever, productive cough, and pleuritic chest pain, support a diagnosis of empyema, which occurs when a parapneumonic effusion progresses to contain purulent material due to infection.

Key learning point: A pleural fluid pH of less than 7.2 is highly suggestive of empyema, which is a collection of pus in the pleural space often associated with bacterial pneumonia.

These cells consume glucose rapidly, leading to low pleural fluid glucose levels. Elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) concentrations indicate the severity of inflammation and the exudative nature of the effusion. The absence of pathogens on gram stain and culture supports an inflammatory rather than infectious cause. This pattern is characteristic of rheumatoid pleuritis, distinguishing it from other exudative effusions.

On examination, she is in moderate respiratory distress with labored breathing. Decreased breath sounds and dullness to percussion are noted over the right lower lung field. Laboratory investigations, including complete blood count and serum chemistries, show no significant abnormalities (see report).

Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Chest tube insertion for continuous drainage

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Chest tube insertion is used for recurrent, loculated, or infected effusions. This patient has a new large effusion with no signs of infection or loculation. Thoracentesis is preferred initially for diagnostic purposes, especially given the suspicion of malignancy.

B) INCORRECT:

Intravenous broad-spectrum antibiotics are indicated for bacterial infections, such as pneumonia with parapneumonic effusion. This patient lacks signs of infection, such as fever or leukocytosis, and the effusion is more likely related to malignancy.

C) INCORRECT:

High-dose loop diuretics manage volume overload in conditions like congestive heart failure, characterized by bilateral effusions and systemic fluid overload signs. This patient, with a unilateral effusion and cancer history, likely has an exudative effusion due to malignancy, not fluid overload.

D) CORRECT:

Thoracentesis serves both therapeutic and diagnostic purposes in this patient with a large right-sided pleural effusion and respiratory distress. The procedure involves draining pleural fluid, which alleviates dyspnea by reducing lung compression. Additionally, analyzing the fluid helps differentiate between exudative and transudative effusions. Given the patient's advanced breast cancer, pleural fluid analysis can assess for malignant involvement, guiding further management.

Key learning point: Thoracentesis is the best initial step in managing a massive pleural effusion to relieve symptoms and obtain fluid for diagnostic analysis.

questions.text:
A 64-year-old woman with stage IV lung adenocarcinoma presents with progressively worsening dyspnea to the clinic. She has undergone three large-volume thoracenteses over the past two months, each showing exudative fluid containing malignant cells. Imaging reveals a large recurrent right-sided pleural effusion. She appears fatigued and hopes to avoid frequent future procedures. On examination, breath sounds are diminished at the right lung base, and she is otherwise hemodynamically stable.
What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While large-volume thoracentesis provides temporary relief from dyspnea due to malignant pleural effusion, it is not a sustainable long-term strategy. Repeated thoracenteses do not prevent fluid reaccumulation and expose the patient to risks such as infection and pneumothorax. The patient desires to reduce the frequency of invasive procedures, making a more durable solution preferable.

B) INCORRECT:

Intrapleural fibrinolytics are used for complicated parapneumonic effusions or empyemas with loculations, not for malignant pleural effusions. Malignant effusions result from cancerous cell involvement, not fibrin deposition. Fibrinolytics do not address the underlying cause of fluid production in malignant effusions.

C) CORRECT:

Talc pleurodesis is a palliative procedure for managing recurrent malignant pleural effusions, particularly in patients with advanced malignancies. It involves instilling talc into the pleural space after complete fluid evacuation and lung re-expansion. The talc induces an inflammatory response, leading to fibrosis and adhesion of the pleural layers, effectively obliterating the pleural space. This reduces fluid reaccumulation and alleviates symptoms like dyspnea. Talc pleurodesis is suitable for patients who have undergone multiple thoracenteses without long-term relief and wish to minimize future invasive procedures.

Key learning point: Chemical pleurodesis is an effective treatment for recurrent malignant pleural effusions, as it prevents re-accumulation of fluid by obliterating the pleural space.

D) INCORRECT:

Empirical antibiotic therapy is indicated for infectious pleural effusions, such as those due to bacterial pneumonia or empyema. This patient's effusion is malignant, as indicated by the presence of malignant cells and the absence of infection signs like fever or leukocytosis. Antibiotics do not address the underlying malignancy-related effusion.

questions.text: You are seeing a 58-year-old man in the emergency department with increasing shortness of breath and a nonproductive cough for the past week. Three weeks ago, he had a fever and cough that lasted 6 days. He reports a 4-kg weight loss over the past 3 months. He has a 41-year history of smoking one pack of cigarettes daily. His temperature is 37.6°C, pulse is 88/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 136/89 mm Hg. On examination, there is dullness to percussion, decreased breath sounds, and decreased tactile fremitus over the left lung base. Cardiac examination is normal. Chest x-ray of this patient is most likely to show which one of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A positive air bronchogram in a patient with dyspnea and a history of cough could indicate lobar pneumonia or alveolar edema. Lobar pneumonia typically manifests with a productive cough, enhanced tactile fremitus, and crackles on auscultation, while alveolar edema manifests with orthopnea and rales and wheezing on auscultation.

B) INCORRECT:

Widening of the intercostal spaces on chest x-ray is caused by chronic hyperinflation of the lungs in emphysema. Emphysema is most commonly seen in individuals with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, which manifests with a chronic productive cough and gradually worsening dyspnea. While tobacco use is the greatest risk factor for developing emphysema, this patient's rapid onset of symptoms makes another diagnosis more likely.

C) INCORRECT:

The deep sulcus sign is a diagnostic finding in patients with pneumothorax. This patient's history of smoking significantly increases his risk of developing a pneumothorax. However, this condition typically manifests with sudden onset of dyspnea and chest pain, as well as hyperresonance on percussion, and is therefore unlikely in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Ground-glass opacities in the lungs can be seen on chest x-ray in the course of infections (e.g., pneumocystis pneumonia), interstitial lung disease (e.g., pulmonary fibrosis), and acute alveolar disease (e.g., pulmonary edema). While all of these conditions may manifest with dyspnea and cough, further characteristic symptoms are absent (e.g., fever, protracted disease course, crackles or rales on auscultation). In addition, ground-glass opacities are frequently hard to detect on x-ray and are better visualized on CT scan.

E) CORRECT:

Blunting of the costophrenic angle is a diagnostic feature of pleural effusion seen on chest x-ray that is caused by the collection of free pleural fluid in the costophrenic recess. Further radiographic features of pleural effusion include a homogeneous density with a meniscus-shaped margin (meniscus sign) as well as complete opacification of the lung and mediastinal shift to the contralateral side in cases of large effusions. Thoracentesis is the most effective method for managing pleural effusion and also allows for analysis of the pleural fluid to help establish the underlying etiology.

This patient's recent weight loss and long history of cigarette smoking suggest that the most likely cause of pleural effusion is lung cancer. A chest CT is indicated to evaluate for signs of malignancy and rule out differential diagnoses (e.g., tuberculosis).

Key learning point: Blunting of the costophrenic angle on chest x-ray is a classic radiographic sign of pleural effusion due to fluid accumulation in the pleural space.
